bibl.title: Transcript of letter fragment from John H. Andrus, [n.d.]

div1.p: Andrus answers questions about Ames and mentions the kindness of Lambert.

div1.head: Transcript of letter fragment from John H. Andrus, [n.d.]
div1.p:
Dr. Ames died without acknowledgment from the government of the
very important part he played.

His widow still lives and - I understand - is not in very good
circumstances. If I can do anything to help make her declining years
more comfortable I am certainly going to do it.

From what Schwieger tells me, Lambert works hard every day. Not
that he is able to but simply because he has to.

My memory is not so short but that I can look back to those days in
the yellow fever hospital when the kindness and consideration of the
big Norseman meant a hell of a lot to me.

I don't know what can be done to get an annuity for Dr. Ames' widow
and Lambert but I'm going to find out.

If it should come to a petition to Congress by we guinea pigs who
are still alive would you sign it?

I feel very certain that I can count on your cooperation and - if you
have any suggestions as to the best way of going about the job -
I will be glad to have them.
Write and tell me all about yourself.

I hope the fates have been treating you kindly - as you well deserve -
and that you are in good health.

closer.salute:
With kindest regards and best wishes.
Sincerely,
closer.seg:
Postscript - If you have the addresses of any of the other yellow
fever victims shall appreciate it very much if you will send them to me.
J.H.A.
